## Overview {.center}

::: {.callout-note appearance="minimal"}
## Today's Learning Objectives

-   Understand the three main types of ANOVA designs and when to use each one
-   Learn how to check and address ANOVA assumptions
-   Master post-hoc testing procedures and interpretation
-   Apply these techniques to your mini-dissertation data
:::

::: notes
Emphasize that ANOVA is a foundational skill for many psychology research designs. Many students will be using some form of ANOVA in their mini-dissertations.
:::
## Using the Writing Guide

::: {.callout-note appearance="minimal"}
### How to Use This Resource

- The Writing Guide is organized to align with our weekly Labs 16-20
- Each lab session focuses on key stages of your mini-dissertation
- Use the guide as a reference before, during, and after each lab
:::

---

::: {.columns}
::: {.column width="50%"}
**The guide includes:**

- Step-by-step instructions

- APA 7 formatting guidelines

- Examples and templates

- Common pitfalls to avoid

:::

::: {.column width="50%"}
**Key components:**

- Main dissertation sections

- Open Materials requirements

- Open Data documentation

- Reflective Account guidance
:::
:::
## Mini-Dissertation Progress Tracker {.smaller}

::: callout-important
### Suggested timeline
:::

::::: columns
::: {.column width="50%"}
**Completed: (feasibly this week)** 

- Data collection ✅ 

- Initial data cleaning ✅ 

- Descriptive statistics ✅
:::

::: {.column width="50%"}
**Up Next: (Lab 17)**

- ANOVA analysis

- Post-hoc tests

- Results write-up 
:::
:::::

## Three Types of ANOVA {.smaller}

::: panel-tabset
### One-Way ANOVA

-   **Purpose**: Compare means across **one independent variable** with 3+ levels

-   **Example**: Effect of three different treatments on anxiety scores

-   **R code**:

    ``` r
    aov(anxiety ~ treatment, data = my_data)
    ```

-   **Key output**: F-statistic, p-value, degrees of freedom

-   **When to use**: Single factor designs in your mini-dissertation

### Factorial ANOVA

-   **Purpose**: Examine effects of **multiple independent variables** and their interactions

-   **Example**: Effects of therapy type (CBT, psychodynamic, or control) and gender on depression scores

-   **R code**:

    ``` r
    aov(depression ~ therapy * gender, data = my_data)
    ```

-   **Key output**: Main effects, interaction effects

-   **When to use**: Multiple factor designs in your mini-dissertation

### Repeated Measures ANOVA

-   **Purpose**: Compare means when same participants measured **multiple times**

-   **Example**: Measuring stress before, during, and after an intervention

-   **R code**:

    ``` r
    # Using {afex} package
    afex::aov_ez(id = "participant", dv = "stress", within = "time_point", data = my_data)
    ```

-   **Key output**: Within-subjects effects, Mauchly's test

-   **When to use**: Longitudinal or repeated testing designs
:::

## ANOVA Assumptions {.smaller}

::::::: r-stack
::: {.fragment .fade-out}
### 1. Independence of Observations

-   Observations should not be influenced by other observations
-   **How to check**: Study design review
-   **If violated**: Consider mixed models or repeated measures design
-   **Mini-dissertation relevance**: Fundamental to valid results



::: {.cell}
::: {.cell-output-display}
![](lab_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-1-1.png){width=960}
:::
:::


:::

::: {.fragment .fade-in-then-out}
### 2. Normality of Residuals

-   Residuals should be normally distributed
-   **How to check**: Q-Q plots, Shapiro-Wilk test
-   **If violated**: Transform data, non-parametric alternatives
-   **Code example**:

``` r
# Check residuals
model <- aov(dv ~ iv, data = my_data)
shapiro.test(residuals(model))
qqnorm(residuals(model)); qqline(residuals(model))
```
:::

::: {.fragment .fade-in-then-out}
### 3. Homogeneity of Variance

-   Groups should have equal variances
-   **How to check**: Levene's test, boxplots
-   **If violated**: Welch's ANOVA, transform data
-   **Code example**:

``` r
# Check homogeneity of variance
car::leveneTest(dv ~ iv, data = my_data)

# If violated, use Welch's ANOVA
oneway.test(dv ~ iv, data = my_data, var.equal = FALSE)
```
:::

::: {.fragment .fade-in}
### Addressing Violations in Mini-Dissertations

Remember to **document all assumption checks** in your methods section:



::: {.cell}
::: {.cell-output-display}
![](lab_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-2-1.png){width=960}
:::
:::



-   [x] **Transparent**: Report all assumption tests
-   [x] **Justified**: Explain any transformations or alternative tests
-   [x] **Complete**: Include visualizations when helpful
:::
:::::::

## Post-Hoc Testing {.smaller}

::::: columns
::: {.column width="60%"}


::: {.cell}
::: {.cell-output-display}
![Visualization of group differences](lab_files/figure-revealjs/fig-posthoc-1.png){#fig-posthoc width=960}
:::
:::


:::

::: {.column width="40%"}
### When ANOVA is significant:

1.  **Tukey HSD** (most common)

    ``` r
    TukeyHSD(aov_model)
    ```

2.  **Bonferroni** (conservative)

    ``` r
    pairwise.t.test(dv, iv, 
                   p.adjust.method = "bonferroni")
    ```

3.  **Games-Howell** (unequal variances)

    ``` r
    rstatix::games_howell_test(data, 
                              Value ~ Group)
    ```

### For your mini-dissertation:

-   Choose based on your design
-   Justify your choice
-   Report all pairwise comparisons
:::
:::::

## APA Style Results Reporting {.smaller}

::: callout-tip
### ANOVA Results Template

```         
A [one-way/factorial/repeated measures] ANOVA was conducted to examine the effect of [IV(s)] on [DV]. 
[Assumption tests were conducted and are reported in the supplementary materials]. 

There was a [significant/non-significant] effect of [IV] on [DV], F([df1], [df2]) = [F-value], 
p = [p-value], partial η² = [effect size]. 

[For significant results:] Post-hoc comparisons using [test name] indicated that the mean score for 
[group 1] (M = [value], SD = [value]) was significantly different from [group 2] (M = [value], 
SD = [value]), p = [p-value].
```
:::

::: {.fragment .fade-in}
### Example:

A one-way ANOVA was conducted to examine the effect of therapy type on anxiety scores. Assumption tests were conducted with no serious violations noted. There was a significant effect of therapy type on anxiety scores, F(2, 87) = 7.34, p = .001, partial η² = .14. Post-hoc comparisons using Tukey's HSD indicated that the mean score for the CBT group (M = 12.4, SD = 3.2) was significantly lower than both the waitlist control group (M = 16.8, SD = 4.1), p \< .001, and the self-help group (M = 15.3, SD = 3.8), p = .023. There was no significant difference between the self-help and waitlist groups (p = .28).
:::

## Interactive Section {.smaller}

::: callout-tip
Work with a partner to complete the following task:
:::



::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code  code-line-numbers="|2-3|5-6|8-9|11-12|14-15"}
# Work through this code with your mini-dissertation data
# 1. Run ANOVA
my_anova <- aov(outcome ~ group, data = my_data)

# 2. Check assumptions
plot(my_anova) # Look at diagnostics plots

# 3. Get ANOVA summary
summary(my_anova)

# 4. Run post-hoc tests
TukeyHSD(my_anova)

# 5. Calculate effect size
effectsize::eta_squared(my_anova)
```
:::



::: {.fragment .fade-in}
### Now discuss:

1.  How would you write up these results in APA style?
2.  What figures would you include to visualize your findings?
3.  What challenges might occur with your own mini-dissertation data?
:::

## Common Mistakes & Solutions {.smaller}

:::::: r-stack
::: {.fragment .fade-out}
### Mistake 1: Ignoring Assumptions

-   **Problem**: Invalid results and conclusions
-   **Solution**: Always check assumptions, report them, and adapt analysis if needed
-   **Mini-dissertation tip**: Include a concise summary of assumption checks in methods
:::

::: {.fragment .fade-in-then-out}
### Mistake 2: Misinterpreting Interaction Effects

-   **Problem**: Focusing only on main effects when interactions are significant
-   **Solution**: Always interpret interactions first when significant
-   **Mini-dissertation tip**: Use interaction plots to visualize and aid interpretation



::: {.cell}
::: {.cell-output-display}
![](lab_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-5-1.png){width=960}
:::
:::


:::

::: {.fragment .fade-in}
### Mistake 3: Over-interpreting Post-hoc Tests

-   **Problem**: Multiple testing inflates Type I error risk
-   **Solution**: Use appropriate corrections; be cautious with interpretations
-   **Mini-dissertation tip**: Focus on effect sizes and confidence intervals, not just p-values

### Mistake 4: Poor Visualization

-   **Problem**: Figures don't clearly show patterns and results
-   **Solution**: Use descriptive, clean visualizations that highlight key findings
-   **Mini-dissertation tip**: Create APA-style figures that could potentially be published
:::
::::::

## Resources & Next Steps {.smaller}

::::: columns
::: {.column width="50%"}
**📚 Resources:** - Field, A. (2018). Discovering Statistics Using IBM SPSS Statistics (Ch. 12-14) - [UCLA's ANOVA Guides](https://stats.oarc.ucla.edu/other/mult-pkg/whatstat/what-statistical-analysis-should-i-usestatistical-analyses-using-spss/) - R packages: {afex}, {emmeans}, {effectsize} - Lab tutorial handout (on LMS)
:::

::: {.column width="50%"}
**📋 To-Do Before Next Lab:** - Complete ANOVA analyses for your mini-dissertation - Create draft figures of your results - Prepare summary of your findings - Bring questions about interpretation to Lab 17
:::
:::::

::: callout-warning
## Important Deadlines

-   Draft analysis completed: \[Date\]
-   Results write-up draft: \[Date\]
-   Final submission: \[Date\]
:::

## Q&A {.center background-color="#3c3c3c"}

::: r-fit-text
Questions?
:::

::: notes
Anticipate questions about: - Choice between different ANOVA types - Handling assumption violations - Interpreting complex interactions - What to do with non-significant findings
:::

------------------------------------------------------------------------

::: r-fit-text
Thank You!
:::

Next Week: Lab 17 - Results Write-up, APA Formatting, Figures and Tables

------------------------------------------------------------------------

include-after-body:
<script>
  // htmlwidgets need to know to resize themselves when slides are shown/hidden.
  // Fire the "slideenter" event (handled by htmlwidgets.js) when the current
  // slide changes (different for each slide format).
  (function () {
    // dispatch for htmlwidgets
    function fireSlideEnter() {
      const event = window.document.createEvent("Event");
      event.initEvent("slideenter", true, true);
      window.document.dispatchEvent(event);
    }

    function fireSlideChanged(previousSlide, currentSlide) {
      fireSlideEnter();

      // dispatch for shiny
      if (window.jQuery) {
        if (previousSlide) {
          window.jQuery(previousSlide).trigger("hidden");
        }
        if (currentSlide) {
          window.jQuery(currentSlide).trigger("shown");
        }
      }
    }

    // hookup for slidy
    if (window.w3c_slidy) {
      window.w3c_slidy.add_observer(function (slide_num) {
        // slide_num starts at position 1
        fireSlideChanged(null, w3c_slidy.slides[slide_num - 1]);
      });
    }

  })();
</script>
